dict.string: Adele Besserman lived as a young child in the Lodz Ghetto in Poland. Her mother took her to Russia in 1941 to escape the ghetto. She returned to Poland after the war and came to the United States in 1949. She took part in the March of the Living in Israel five years in a row, taking 75-100 children with her.

Anna Krakowsky worked in a munitions factory in a concentration camp in the country of her birth, Poland, before being moved to the another camp in Poland. She was liberated in January, 1945, and got married the same year in a displaced persons camp in Germany.

Bella Landau’s life was spared when she was taken out of the Auschwitz crematorium at the last minute. She was moved to Birkenau, then Muhlhausen, and then Bergen-Belsen. She was finally liberated by the Americans from Salzwedel camp in Germany. She came to the United States in 1957.

Bella Schwartzberg’s parents were born in Lodz, Poland. They moved to Brazil where she was born. However, they returned to Poland in 1939 and were put into the ghetto. They left from Lodz in 1943 and returned to Brazil.

Bernard Brown was born in Poland in 1919. He was in the Lida Ghetto where his father, mother, and sisters died. He ran away but was put in a labor camp in Russia where he was eventually liberated. He went to Israel in 1959 for two years. He was the only survivor in his family.

Hannah Biegelisen was born in Lodz, Poland in 1931. She lived in a ghetto for four years and did one year of forced labor in Auschwitz where she lost all her family. Her husband to be, Ben Biegelisen, spent four years in Auschwitz where his whole family perished. He was liberated from there by Russian forces and went to Israel in 1945. He fought in the army in the War of Independence and met Hannah in Israel after she spent six months in Cyprus in 1947. They both came to the United States in 1959 with no money and without knowing any English. They first lived in New York and then moved to Florida.

Edith Akerman was born in Czechoslovakia/Poland in 1920. She was moved from the Czestochowa Ghetto and was in the concentration camps at Terezin, Berga, Thuringia, Bergen-Belsen, and Dachau. She was on a death march at 22 years old and was liberated from Dachau in 1945. She came to the United States in 1950.

Eugenia Rosen was hidden by Catholic nuns in a convent in Poland. Her mother paid different people to hide her during the war. Her mother and father both survived too. Eugenia wrote a letter to her grandson telling her experiences when he was going to see Treblinka.

Ester Ross was born in Lodz, Poland, in 1924. She lived in a ghetto, and today she states that she “did my duty in hell already” within the ghetto, before being deported to Auschwitz for four days. She was lined up for the gas chambers but was sent to Bergen-Belsen for a few months. She was transferred to Salzwedel female camp in East Germany where she worked in an ammunitions factory. When soldiers came to liberate the Salzwedel camp in April 1945, they cried because the prisoners were like skeletons. The previous day, the German commandant refused to carry out orders to kill the prisoners. Ester never saw her mother and brother again after being separated in Auschwitz. Another sister died there, her father died in 1942, and one sister fled to Russia. Ester came to the United States in August 1946 with $5 and she worked sewing. Ester visited Israel in 1962 and 1972.

Florence Braun Hershkowitz was born in Poland in 1932. When she was six years old, she left the Majdanek concentration camp with her sister and brother and escaped to Russia with her parents. They ended up in Siberia, where they suffered terribly from hunger and picked berries to survive. She still has scars from scurvy. Her husband also survived the Holocaust. After returning to Poland, she came to the United States with her family in 1945.

George Freshman was born in Poland in 1925. He survived both the Grolec and Warsaw ghettos in Poland. He also survived nine different concentration camps and was liberated from Dachau. George came to the United States in 1949 where he worked in real estate. His brother and sister escaped to Russia, and the rest of the family perished. He has visited Israel many times.

Howard and Nancy Kleinberg were born in Poland in 1926 and 1929 respectively. They survived Auschwitz before being deported to Bergen-Belsen. They were both liberated from Bergen-Belsen where Nancy first met and assisted Howard when he was sick and lying on the ground the day after liberation. He spent six months recovering in hospital. Nancy came to the United States in 1947, and Howard came to Canada where they met the same year. They now live in Toronto. They have visited Israel several times.

Born in Poland in 1928, Isidor Schleicher made shoes and uniforms in Lipoza 7 concentration camp near Majdanek as a twelve-year-old. In 1944, he ran away from the camp to the woods. He lived in Israel from 1948-1996 when he came to the United States. Spielberg did a three-hour interview with Isidor on the Shoah archive

Jack Waksal was born in Poland in 1924. He was in the Jaldns Ghetto until the end of 1940 when he went to the Kruszny and another forced labor camp where he worked on German aircraft. He was in another camp from 1942-1944, and on the march from there to Auschwitz, he ran into the forest and was liberated from there. He came to the United States in 1950 after having married in Europe.
Jack Rotmench was born in Poland in 1920. He survived Bunzlau concentration camp.
Jack Senfield was born in Poland in 1941. He never was in a concentration camp but lived in Kassel displaced persons’ camp for three years. His wife Rita was born in a displaced persons’ camp.

Jerry Kaidanow was born in Poland in 1933, and was part of the Dokshitz Ghetto. He joined the partisan resistance in Belarus and his brother was part of the partisan group with Abba Kovner. He was liberated by the Russian Army in Belarus. Jerry came to the United States in 1947 and worked as a real estate broker. His wife was saved by a Gentile. His niece works for the Assistant Secretary of State for the United States.

Joseph Poslun was born in Poland in 1927. He was deported from the Sosnowiec Ghetto to Auschwitz and then moved to Buchenwald. He was sent as a mechanic to Sachsenhausen but worked there moving stones from one place to another. More than half of the 400 workers died in 2 weeks. He was on the death march from Gross-Rosen to Buchenwald, and in two weeks of walking in the snow, only a few hundred of 4,000 survived. He was liberated from hospital in Sachsenhausen camp. He survived because he was with Rothchild, a friend from one of the wealthiest families in France. For two years, he worked with survivors in Brocha and smuggled over 250.000 people from Communist countries to the west. In 1948, he volunteered with the Israeli Army, where he met his wife. He came to the United States in 1960 with one daughter, and he had only one sister to survive the Holocaust.

Julius Eisenstein was born in Poland in 1919. He survived the Tonaszson maz Ghetto as well as Auschwitz concentration camp and the slave labor camps in Blizyn, Sachsenhausen, and Dachau from where he was liberated. He came to the United States in 1950 where he worked as a baker. He lost his father, mother, and three sisters, and his one brother survived. He speaks to students and other groups about his experiences.

Larry Hershkowitz was born in Lodz, Poland, in 1923. He lived in the Lodz Ghetto for three years until it was liquidated. He lost his father, brother, and a sister when food was no longer supplied. He jumped into a garbage can to escape a trap of being offered food by the Germans to mark them for deportation. However, he obeyed his dying mother’s request to surrender with his sister to the police. He was deported to Auschwitz and then moved to the Mauthausen concentration camp in Austria. He was liberated from there in March 1944 by Americans. He almost died from food poisoning, but recovered in hospital in Linz. He came to the United States in 1947, and he had only one younger sister to survive the Holocaust. He has visited Israel.

Lea Kisser Kronenberg was born in 1931. She was moved from the Lodz Ghetto to Auschwitz, and then to a camp in Belgium. Eventually she went to Bergen-Belsen, where she was liberated. She was just over seventeen years old when she came to the United States in 1949.

Leo Rosner was born in Poland in 1929. He was hidden in an attic when he was thirteen years old, along with his mother and sister. He lived in the Krakow Ghetto and survived seven camps including Buchenwald, Mauthausen, Fleshburg, Plaszow in Poland, and Flosverg in Germany. He survived work in construction and munition factories in death camps and also typhus. He was liberated by Captain Lebi of the Jewish brigade from Mauthausen when he was sixteen years old. He came to the United States in March 29, 1948 on a student visa, and President Truman soon ruled that anyone who came before April 1 could be given a permanent visa. He served in the United States’ Army in intelligence from 1952, and he spent one year in Germany. His father and one uncle survived the Holocaust. His dying mother had told him, “You must promise me my child, you will survive.” His current wife is Cuban and her family were all killed in Treblinka. Leo has written a book The Holocaust Remembered and speaks at schools to teach the future generations about his experience. Leo also participated in Germany in a trial of Gestapo in Poland, where he recognized four Gestapo officers.

Louis Radzeli was born in 1918 in Wilno, Poland. He worked in forced labor in a ghetto from 1941-1944. Most of his family were shot in a mass grave, but he ran and hid. He was eventually liberated from the ghetto by the Russians, and he lived in a displaced persons house. He came to New Jersey in 1951 and started his own business in Cleveland in 1955. He visits Israel every 3-4 years.
Lucille Bernheim was born in Poland in 1931. She is the sister of Sonia Lowenbraun.

Mike Alpert was born in Poland in 1931. He lived in a ghetto from 1941-42. He then survived in the forestfourfrom 1942-44 and was liberated by the Russian army. Mike has gone to Israel about forty times from 1963-2014, sometimes going twice a year.

Marvin Zborowski was born in Poland in 1926. He lived in the Zarki Ghetto and was hidden with his mother, brother, and sister in an attic for two years by a Polish Christian family. His father was killed by the Germans. He was liberated from Zarki by the Russians. He came to the United States in 1952 and became a successful businessman in New York. He first visited Israel in 1950 and has visited very often since. His brother Eli was Chairman for Yad Vashem in the United States, and he has been Treasurer of Yad Vashem in the United States.
Mary Tintenfass was born in Poland in 1930. She survived the Leipzig concentration camp and came to New York in 1949. She became a realtor in New Jersey and New York.

Born in Poland in 1927, Miriam Rosenbaum survived a ghetto and a forced labor camp in Germany. After being liberated from Reichenbach by the Russians, she lived in Landsberg, Germany, in a displaced persons camp. She has visited Israel many times.

Morris Friedlich was born in Poland in 1925. His family’s shoe store was closed by the SS. His father took Morris and his brother across the border to Czechoslovakia when in danger to stay with an aunt. He and his brother then went to Hungary where an underground Zionist organization gave them money. They were given Christian papers and survived the war there.

Naomi Weinfeld was born in Poland in 1938. She escaped the war by going to Russia with her older sister. Her brother was born in Russia. She was liberated in Russia, and in 1956 she married her husband who was in Auschwitz at thirteen years old. She came to Canada that year.

Paul Gast was born in Lodz, Poland, in 1929. He was deported from the Theresienstadt Ghetto to Auschwitz. He was liberated by the 82nd Airborne Division and came to the United States in 1951, where he became an accountant. He has visited Israel.
Phylis Talit was born in Poland in 1927 and survived Buchenwald concentration camp.

Born in 1923, Rosalie Steinweis was deported from a ghetto in Poland to Parschnitz, a sub-camp of Gross-Rosen in Czechoslovakia. She was liberated on May 8, 1945, the last day of the war. Rosalie got married and had a child before coming to the United States in 1947. She worked as a seamstress in the United States.
Rose Rotmench, born in Poland in 1925, survived several concentration camps including Bergen-Belsen. Her parents went on death marches.

Sally Dauman (nee Jachimowitz) was born in Lodz, Poland, in 1926. She was deported from the Lodz Ghetto to Auschwitz and then went to Bergen-Belsen and Salzwedel camps. She was liberated from the ammunitions factory there. She came to the United States in 1946. She met her husband (now deceased) in Germany, and has one adopted daughter. She goes to schools to teach children about the Holocaust.

Sam Schwartzberg was born in Zamosc, Poland, in 1923. He was found in a synagogue where he was living, and he was sent to a prisoner camp in the Taiga Forest in Siberia. He ran away but was caught and put in a small ghetto. From 1943-35 he was free but still in Russia. After the war he lived first in Poland and then in Berlin. He came to Canada in 1951.
Shelia Springer survived the Warsaw Ghetto. She also lived through four concentration camps including Majdanek, Auschwitz, and Ravensbruck. She came to the United States right after the war.
Sonia Lowenbraun was born in Poland. She was hidden with her mother and three sisters, and they all survived. Her mother and father took turns to go out of hiding to get food for their family.

Shary Arem was deported to Auschwitz in a cattle car when she was fourteen years old. Her mother told her to stay with her cousin at selection. She lost her father and mother and brother there. Shary was liberated from Danzig by the Russians. She has visited Israel many times. Her uncle in America sent her papers to come here in 1948.

Stella Sonnenschein was born in Warsaw, Poland, in 1935. She was smuggled out of the Warsaw Ghetto when she was seven years old by a Catholic woman and hidden by Polish families. Her mother survived the war and by a miracle found her daughter about a year after the war ended. They returned to Lodz, Poland.

Yona Bromberg was born in Poland in 1940. She lived in the Rokitna Ghetto before running to hide in the woods when rounded up in the town square. She and her mother and sister were in the woods for eighteen months before being liberated. She came to the United States in 1961 and then to Toronto in Canada. She is a teacher and speaker on the Holocaust because “all my relatives cannot speak.”
